conns.from: Brandr the myth, the lengend, the man

conns.to: The Toreador Anna Hyde of the Queen's Knights
Brandr the myth, the lengend, the man

conns.from: The Toreador Anna Hyde of the Queen's Knights

page.description:
Fragments of the coterie, the Egyptologist and Bill, once the heirs to the British Empire, drifts back to London after years in hiding to assess whatever they can salvage of their once vast resources.


The past century-or-so have been nothing but a decline since the height of their promise, at their introduction to the Vampire Club on the Strand in 1899, with a sharp downturn at the end.
The Second Inquisition, the Fall of London, and the Conclave of Prague in 2012 shattered the Camarilla, and thus the coterie. The fallout of the Second Convention of Prague in 2021 destroyed whatever remained. More than a hundred years of work down the drain, with a bitter aftertaste of betrayal.

The Egyptologist and Bill have chosen to crawl out of hiding because they have made contact with one of their peers -- the Toreador Anna Hyde of the Queen’s Knights -- who has agreed to meet them on Southbank if they adhere to her rules: no cells phones or electronic devices, and they will talk for less than fifteen minutes.

As the Egyptologist and Bill prepare to seek out Hyde, they spend a few nights reminiscing about their grand past as empire builders, and learn the rules of their once grand domain, now a desolate ghost town overrun by the living.
page.name: 1 - Chapter One: The Ghost Town
Adventuring Group

page.name: Alignment

page.briefSummary: A viking captain reborn in leather and steel, outlaw and noble, a relic of storm and sea who still burns with the need for loyalty, fury
page.description:
Brandr walks into a room like the tide coming in — slow, unstoppable, carrying the weight of centuries. Broad-shouldered and bearded, with long hair tied back and streaked with silver, he has the look of a man who once commanded a ship in stormy seas. His skin is weathered like old oak, his eyes glinting with the fire of a hearth and the fury of a battlefield.

Across his arms, throat, and knuckles coil tattoos: Norse runes, longships, wolves, and scars of faith inked into his flesh across a thousand nights. His clothes are anachronistic but powerful — a heavy leather jacket that fits him like armour, tailored shirts beneath, silver rings and chains that gleam like trophies. He could be mistaken for a biker warlord, or perhaps an eccentric collector — but something about him feels older, truer, more dangerous.

He is both sword and spark: a warrior with brutal strength, and a firebrand who ignites passion and rebellion in those around him. His voice can rise like thunder to command a crowd, or fall to a low growl that makes men lean in closer without knowing why.

Brandr has always been the Captain — never the king, never the chieftain, but the trusted second-in-command whose loyalty bound men together. Across a millennium he has outlived jarls, lords, and princes, but he still seeks that bond of blood and trust: a crew worth fighting for. He cannot abide betrayal, and when provoked, his fury is as sudden and violent as a storm at sea.

In modern London, Brandr has carved out a following of bikers, pagans, and outcasts who wear his wolf-and-axes patch as a badge of loyalty. To the world they are just another gang — but to him they are his modern longship crew, The Oathbound. They call him Captain, and he answers with a mix of rough affection and iron discipline.

Yet beneath the leather and steel, Brandr harbors an unexpected fondness: medieval fairs and historical reenactments. Among the tents and the clash of blunted swords, he feels echoes of the old world and a fleeting sense of belonging. It was in this world that he met his Touchstone, Edward “Ned” Ashcroft — a wealthy lawyer playing Viking — and where he often finds recruits among neo-pagans and romantics hungry for meaning. For a few moments at these events, the Captain is more than a predator; he is a man remembering who he once was.

There is a strange duality in him. On one hand, he is a relic — a Viking mariner who carries the weight of forgotten raids and lost jarls. On the other, he is fully present in the neon glow of 2025, a leather-clad outlaw who thrives in the chaos of the streets. He is both beast and gentleman, both pagan and philosopher, a man who can toast you in an East London dive bar or break your jaw in the alley outside.

Above all, Brandr is loyal — to his crew, to his word, to the idea that a man’s worth is proven not by wealth or lineage but by what he can hold together when the storm breaks.

Theme & Flair in Short:
Brandr is a Viking captain reborn in leather and steel, equal parts outlaw and noble, a relic of storm and sea who still burns with the need for loyalty, fury, and the eternal fire of rebellion — with fleeting solace found in the echoes of medieval fairs and the mortals who chase the past.

 

 

 

Character Sheet: Brandr the Captain (V5)

Name: Brandr Sveinsson
Clan: Brujah
Sire: Unknown (fellow raider)
Generation: 10th
Predator Type: Osiris (leader of The Oathbound biker gang)
Chronicle Tenet Tie: Loyalty above all else

Attributes

Physical

  • Strength ••••

  • Dexterity •••

  • Stamina •••

Social

  • Charisma •••

  • Manipulation ••

  • Composure ••

Mental

  • Intelligence ••

  • Wits •••

  • Resolve •••

Skills

Physical

  • Athletics ••

  • Brawl •••

  • Drive ••

  • Melee •••

Social

  • Intimidation •••

  • Leadership •••

  • Persuasion ••

  • Streetwise ••

Mental

  • Awareness ••

  • Occult •

  • Academics •• (Specialty: Norse/Victorian History)

Disciplines

  • Potence •• — Soaring Leap, Lethal Body

  • Celerity •• — Cat’s Grace, Rapid Reflexes

  • Presence • — Awe

Advantages

Backgrounds

  • Allies •• (The Oathbound inner circle)

  • Haven •• (Abandoned Thames warehouse, fortified)

  • Resources • (Gang hustles and smuggling)

  • Fame • (Within London biker/pagan subculture)

  • Herd ••• (The Oathbound and their hangers-on)

Predator Type: Osiris

  • Benefit: Herd •••, extra dots in Presence

  • Drawback: Constant scrutiny — followers attract attention from rivals, authorities, and hunters.

Clan Bane (Brujah)

Quick to anger — difficulty to resist frenzy increases when insulted, restrained, or witnessing betrayal.

Convictions & Touchstones

  • Conviction 1: Never betray your crew.

  • Conviction 2: Strength must be proven, not bought.

  • Touchstone: Edward “Ned” Ashcroft — wealthy lawyer and Viking reenactor, fragile mirror of Brandr’s past.

Ambition & Desire

  • Ambition: To rise from Captain to Jarl — to lead in his own right.

  • Desire: To command loyalty and protect a crew bound by blood.

Humanity

  • Score: 6 (anchored by loyalty and Ned Ashcroft)

  • Stains: Violence against innocents, betrayal of trust.

Willpower

  • Dots: 6 (Resolve ••• + Composure ••)

  • Current: To be tracked in play.

Health & Hunger

  • Health: 6

  • Hunger: Starts at 1, max 5.

Equipment & Style

  • Leather biker jacket with The Oathbound wolf-and-axes patch.

  • Silver rings, chain, tattoos across arms and throat.

  • Weapons: Modern combat knife, occasional axe (personal flair).

Notes for Play

  • Brandr is not subtle — his power lies in presence, loyalty, and raw force.

  • His gang functions as Herd and Allies but are also his greatest vulnerability.

  • Frenzy triggers: betrayal, insults to loyalty, threats against his crew.

Summary:
Brujah Viking captain, leather-clad outlaw, and firebrand leader. Wields fists, fury, and charisma with equal force. Anchored by loyalty, haunted by centuries, he walks London as both warrior and spark.
page.name: Brandr the Captain

page.briefSummary: How he might be spoken of by others and by himself
page.description:
Here’s how Brandr might be spoken of by others, giving him that mythic, street-level presence in both mortal and Kindred circles:

How Mortals Talk About Him

  • “That bloke down by the docks? The one with the wolf patch crew? They call him Captain. Don’t cross him. Don’t even look at him too long.”

  • “He’s into all that Viking shit — tattoos, runes, the lot. But when he talks, you feel it. Like he believes it, like he lived it.”

  • “He’s not like the other biker bosses. Most of ‘em are loudmouths. Him? He’s quiet until he isn’t — and when he snaps, you’ll pray you’re not in his way.”

  • “Some say he’s a re-enactor, others say he’s descended from raiders. All I know is, he fights like a man who’s done it before. For real.”

How Kindred Talk About Him

  • “The Captain? That one’s old. You can smell the salt air on him, like he’s been at sea for a thousand years.”

  • “He’s Brujah, no doubt. Quick to anger, quick to inspire. The kind who can rally a mob or tear it apart with his bare hands.”

  • “Funny thing about him — he plays at being just another Anarch with a gang, but I’ve seen elders listen when he speaks. He has the weight of ages in him.”

  • “Call him Captain if you like. But don’t forget — he’s been waiting to be Jarl for a very, very long time.”

His Myth in the Streets

Among mortals, Brandr is a whispered legend — the “Viking biker,” the Captain who never loses a fight and always takes care of his crew. Among Kindred, he’s a respected anachronism — too stubborn to die, too dangerous to dismiss, and too charismatic to ignore.

Street-Level Impression in Short:
To mortals, he’s a dangerous outlaw with Viking fire in his blood. To Kindred, he’s a relic-warrior with the weight of the old world — a Captain who might one night finally claim the title of Jarl.

 

Brandr’s Voice

"They call me Captain. Not King, not Jarl — Captain. I’ve been that since the old days, when I took a longship west with thirty men who trusted me with their lives. I was never the one with the crown, but I was the one who brought them home. Loyalty, that’s what mattered then. Still does.

Now it’s bikes instead of ships, concrete instead of sea, but the crew is the same. Men and women who’ll bleed with you, stand when the storm hits. That’s all I ever wanted — not thrones, not crowns. Just a crew that holds the line.

So hear me clear: I don’t care who you kneel to in this city, or what titles you whisper in Elysium. If you break your word, if you betray your own… you’ll answer to me. And I’ve been collecting debts a very long time."

Shorter tagline-style version (if you need it for quick flavour):
“Not a king. Not a prince. I am the Captain. Break your oath, and you’ll learn what that means.”

 

Here’s how Brandr might pitch himself to mortals and his gang, stripped of the undead politics but still raw, commanding, and magnetic:

Brandr to Mortals / The Oathbound

"You can call me Captain. Always have, always will. I don’t need a throne, I don’t need a crown — I need people who stand their ground when the world comes swinging. That’s the only law I live by: loyalty.

The weak buy it with money. The loud shout it with words. Me? I prove it with blood and fire. You ride with me, you fight with me, you bleed with me — and I’ll make damn sure no one touches you without going through me first.

So don’t talk about family unless you mean it. Don’t wear the wolf unless you’re ready to bare your teeth. Break your oath, and you’re nothing. Keep it, and you’ll live forever in the roar of the storm."

Short, street-flavoured tagline:
“Loyalty isn’t words. It’s blood. You keep your oath, and I’ll keep you standing.”
page.name: Brandr the myth, the lengend, the man

page.name: Role

page.briefSummary: A modern outlaw biker gang with Viking flair. The Oathbound are half-gang, half-cult  loyal to Brandr as their Captain
page.description:
Brandr’s Crew: The Oathbound

Theme: A modern outlaw biker gang with Viking flair. The Oathbound are half-gang, half-cult — loyal to Brandr as their Captain, and infused with Norse myth and imagery. To mortals, they are a rough band of bikers; to Kindred, they are a living reflection of a Brujah Viking’s need for loyalty, battle, and fire.

The Inner Circle — The Oathbound Proper

Brandr’s closest companions, treated as a modern longship crew:

  • Skald (Jamie Kerr)
    Role: Storyteller and hype-man. Runs social media, curates music, spins tales of Brandr’s glory.
    Look: Lean, tattooed, sharp-tongued, always with a phone in hand.
    Function: Turns Brandr into a legend among mortals.

  • Bear (Connor Doyle)
    Role: Muscle and enforcer.
    Look: Huge, bald, covered in tattoos; terrifying in a fight, soft-spoken in private.
    Function: The shieldman, Brandr’s most loyal protector.

  • Witch (Sasha Mikelson)
    Role: Occultist and spiritualist.
    Look: Gothic-pagan, ritual scars, always surrounded by incense.
    Function: Dabbles in Norse rites and magic, giving the gang spiritual depth.

  • Rat (Lewis Harker)
    Role: Scavenger and fixer.
    Look: Scrawny, twitchy, always chewing gum, a streetwise hustler.
    Function: Secures bikes, weapons, safehouses, and information.

  • Shieldmaiden (Kelly Grant)
    Role: Second-in-command, fiercely loyal lieutenant.
    Look: Tattooed, strong, sharp-eyed; leather jacket adorned with runes.
    Function: Brandr’s right hand, future ghoul or Embrace candidate.

The Outer Circle — The Deckhands

Mortals who orbit the gang, providing resources, admiration, and cover:

  • Hangarounds: Young bikers and street punks desperate for recognition. Run errands and prove loyalty.

  • Enthusiasts: Viking reenactors, neo-pagans, and history buffs drawn to the crew’s imagery. They see Brandr as living heritage.

  • Sympathisers: Bartenders, mechanics, and small-time criminals who support the gang for protection or profit.

The Fringe — The Wake

The broader following, more fanbase than gang:

  • Festival Fans: Admirers from fairs, fight reenactments, or Skald’s online presence.

  • Romantics: Lovers and admirers swept up by the outlaw myth.

  • Wannabes: People who wear wolf patches or Norse tattoos to signal affiliation, though they’re not true members.

Symbols & Identity

  • Name: The Oathbound — loyalty above all.

  • Patch/Symbol: A wolf’s head with crossed axes.

  • Territory: Old warehouses and pubs near the Thames, with influence stretching into East London.

  • Activities: Smuggling, protection rackets, biker runs, reenactment festivals as cover, underground fights.

Function in Play

  • Feeding Ground: Provides a steady flow of mortals for Brandr’s Hunger, framed as loyalty rituals.

  • Muscle: Ready to back Brandr or the coterie in street-level conflicts.

  • Weak Spot: Their numbers and visibility draw attention from rivals, police, or hunters.

  • Story Hooks: Witch’s occult dabbling, Shieldmaiden’s ambition for Embrace, Skald’s media drawing too much heat.

What They Believe

  • They call Brandr “Captain,” believing he’s just a charismatic, half-mad outlaw with deep Viking obsession.

  • Skald spreads the myth that he’s descended from raiders, which everyone half-believes.

  • Witch whispers that he’s more than mortal — Brandr neither confirms nor denies.

Gang Structure

  • Symbol: A wolf’s head with crossed axes (painted on jackets and bikes).

  • Territory: Old warehouses and pubs by the Thames, with routes into East London.

  • Activities: Low-level smuggling, “protection” rackets, reenactment festivals as cover, occasional underground fights.

In gameplay, they’re not just flavour — they give Brandr:

  • Feeding ground (Osiris Predator Type).

  • Muscle for physical conflict.

  • Weak spot (threats to his “crew” are Frenzy triggers).

  • Story hooks (Witch dabbling in real occult, Shieldmaiden demanding Embrace, Skald attracting police or press attention).

Summary:
The Oathbound are more than a gang — they are Brandr’s modern warband. With a tight inner circle and a wider orbit of followers, they are both his strength and his greatest vulnerability, reflecting the eternal struggle of loyalty, fire, and rebellion that defines a Brujah Viking Captain.
page.name: The Oathbound
The Toreador Anna Hyde of the Queen's Knights

page.description: The vampires of Ixalan are similar to the classic tales of the immortal undead. Unlike their counterparts in other realms, however, these creatures are not bound only to nighttime roaming.
page.name: Vampire
